block.p: Margaret Anne Murray and Bruce Edward Fleming are to be married today in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Mary Tiebout, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.
The bride, 35, is the Medicaid director for the State of New Jersey in Trenton. She graduated cum laude from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in public affairs from Princeton.

Margaret Anne Murray and Bruce Edward Fleming are to be married today in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Mary Tiebout, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.
The bride, 35, is the Medicaid director for the State of New Jersey in Trenton. She graduated cum laude from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in public affairs from Princeton.

Ms. Murray, who is keeping her name, is the daughter of Dr. Margaret Thorell of Philadelphia and Jack Murray of Hughesville, Pa., and the stepdaughter of Prof. Klaus Krippendorff and of Suzanne Murray. The bride's father is the founder of the Knockroe Group, a management consulting company in Hughesville. Her mother is the vice president for editorial services at Trinity Communications Inc., a health care communications company, in Conshohocken, Pa. The bride's stepfather is a professor of communications at the Annenberg School of the University of Pennsylvania. Her stepmother retired as the vice president for financial strategy at Dun & Bradstreet in New York.

Mr. Fleming, 45, is a professor of English at the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md. He graduated from Haverford College, and received a master's degree in comparative literature from the University of Chicago and a Ph.D. in comparative literature from Vanderbilt University. He was a Fulbright fellow at the Free University of Berlin and later the Fulbright professor at the National University of Rwanda. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

He is the son of Dr. Jessie L. Fleming and Dr. Maurice C. Fleming, both of Salisbury, Md. Both of the bridegroom's parents retired from Salisbury State University, where his mother was a professor of music and his father a professor of education.
